      have : ¬¨2 ^ (m.factorization 2 + 1) ‚à£ m := pow_succ_padicValNat_not_dvd hmzero
      have : m1.Coprime 2 := by
        nth_rw 2 [heq] at this
        have : ¬¨ 2 ‚à£ m1 := by
          intro hdvd
          have hfalse : 2 ^ (m.factorization 2 + 1) ‚à£ 2 ^ m.factorization 2 * m1 := by
            have eq: 2 ^ (m.factorization 2 + 1) = 2 ^ m.factorization 2 * 2 := by
              exact rfl
            rw [eq]
            exact Nat.mul_dvd_mul_left (2 ^ m.factorization 2) hdvd
          exact this hfalse
        refine Nat.coprime_two_right.mpr ?_
        refine Nat.odd_iff.mpr ?_
        exact Nat.two_dvd_ne_zero.mp this
      have : m1.Coprime (2 ^ (m.factorization 2)) := Nat.Coprime.pow_right (m.factorization 2) this
      rw [heq, Nat.totient_mul (Nat.coprime_comm.mp this)]
      rw [Nat.totient_prime_pow (by norm_num) hfacpos]
      simp
      group
      calc
        _ = m1.totient * (2 ^ (m.factorization 2 - 1) * 2) := by group
        _ = m1.totient * 2 ^ (m.factorization 2 -1 + 1) := rfl
        _ = m1.totient * 2 ^ (m.factorization 2) := by rw [Nat.sub_add_cancel hfacpos]
        _ ‚â§ _ := Nat.mul_le_mul_right (2 ^ m.factorization 2) (Nat.totient_le m1)

  -- Step 3: Prove that the totient of `a m` is even for `m > 2`
  have heven : ‚àÄ m > 2, Even m.totient := by
    intro n
    apply Nat.totient_even

  -- Step 4: Prove that `a m` is even for all `m > 0` and `m ‚â§ n - 1`
  have h1 : ‚àÄ m, m > 0 ‚àß m ‚â§ n-1 -> Even (a m) := by
    intro m hm
    have := h m hm
    rw [this]
    apply heven
    apply hge
    constructor
    ¬∑ linarith
    ¬∑ apply Nat.add_le_of_le_sub (by linarith) hm.2

  -- Step 5: Prove that `a m ‚â• 2 * a (m-1)` for `m > 1` and `m ‚â§ n - 1`
  have h2 : ‚àÄ m, m > 1 ‚àß m ‚â§ n-1 -> a (m) ‚â• 2 * (a (m-1)) := by
    intro m hm
    have heq : a (m-1) = (a m ).totient := by
      have : m - 1 > 0 ‚àß m - 1 ‚â§ n-1 := by
        constructor
        ¬∑ apply Nat.zero_lt_sub_of_lt hm.1
        ¬∑ calc
            _ ‚â§ n - 1 - 1:= by apply Nat.sub_le_sub_right hm.2 1
            _ ‚â§ _ := Nat.sub_le_succ_sub (n - 1) 1
      have := h (m-1) this
      have hmeq : m -1 + 1 = m := Nat.sub_add_cancel (by linarith)
      rw [hmeq] at this
      exact this
    have : Even (a m) := h1 m ‚ü®(by linarith), hm.2‚ü©
    have : 2 * (a m).totient ‚â§ a m := htotient (a m) this
    rw [‚Üê heq] at this
    exact this

  -- Step 6: Prove that `a m ‚â• 2 ^ m` for all `m > 0` and `m ‚â§ n - 1`
  have h2pow : ‚àÄ m, m > 0 ‚àß m ‚â§ n-1 -> a m ‚â• 2 ^ (m) := by
    intro m
    induction m with
    | zero =>
      intro hfalse
      linarith
    | succ m hm =>
      by_cases hmzero : m = 0
      ¬∑ intro _
        rw [hmzero]
        simp
        linarith
      ¬∑ intro hmsucc
        have : m > 0 ‚àß m ‚â§ n-1:= by
          constructor
          ¬∑ exact Nat.zero_lt_of_ne_zero hmzero
          ¬∑ linarith
        have hmge := hm this
        have := h2 (m+1) ‚ü®(by linarith), hmsucc.2‚ü©
        simp at this
        calc
          _ ‚â• 2 * a m := this
          _ ‚â• 2 * 2 ^ m := by linarith
          _ = _ := by group

  -- Step 7: Combine results to conclude `a n ‚â• 2 ^ (n-1)`
  have : a (n-1) ‚â• 2 ^ (n-1) := by
    apply h2pow (n-1)
    constructor
    ¬∑ exact Nat.zero_lt_sub_of_lt hn
    ¬∑ linarith
  have hgen : a n ‚â• a (n-1) := by
    have : a (n-1) = (a n).totient := by
      have han := h (n-1) ‚ü®Nat.zero_lt_sub_of_lt hn, (by linarith)‚ü©
      rw [han]
      have hneq : n - 1 + 1 = n := Nat.sub_add_cancel (by linarith)
      rw [hneq]
    rw [this]
    exact Nat.totient_le (a n)
  linarith

soln_description:
Let $a_{n}=\frac{x^{n}-y^{n}}{x-y}$, then $a_{1}=1, a_{2}=x+y$, and for any $n \geq 1$,

$$
a_{n+2}=\frac{x^{n+2}-y^{n+2}}{x-y}=\frac{(x+y)\left(x^{n+1}-y^{n+1}\right)-\left(x y^{n+1}-y x^{n+1}\right)}{x-y}=(x+y) a_{n+1}-x y a_{n}
$$

If we show that $x+y$ and $x y$ are integers, then on one hand $a_{1}$ and $a_{2}$ are integers, and on the other hand, if $a_{k+1}$ and $a_{k}$ are integers, then necessarily $a_{k+2}=(x+y) a_{k+1}-x y a_{k}$ is also an integer. From this, by induction on $n$, it follows that $a_{m}$ is an integer for all $m$.

Suppose that (for some $n$) $a_{n}, a_{n+1}, a_{n+2}, a_{n+3}$ are all integers. Since

$$
\begin{aligned}
& a_{n} a_{n+3}-a_{n+1} a_{n+2}=\frac{\left(x^{n}-y^{n}\right)\left(x^{n+3}-y^{n+3}\right)-\left(x^{n+1}-y^{n+1}\right)\left(x^{n+2}-y^{n+2}\right)}{(x-y)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{x^{n} y^{n}\left(x^{2} y+x y^{2}-x^{3}-y^{3}\right)}{(x-y)^{2}}=\frac{x^{n} y^{n}(x+y)\left(2 x y-x^{2}-y^{2}\right)}{(x-y)^{2}}=-x^{n} y^{n}(x+y)
\end{aligned}
$$

it follows that $x^{n} y^{n}(x+y)$ is an integer. Similarly,

$$
\begin{aligned}
a_{n+2} a_{n}-a_{n+1}^{2} & =\frac{\left(x^{n+2}-y^{n+2}\right)\left(x^{n}-y^{n}\right)-\left(x^{n+1}-y^{n+1}\right)^{2}}{(x-y)^{2}}= \\
& =\frac{x^{n} y^{n}\left(2 x y-x^{2}-y^{2}\right)}{(x-y)^{2}}=-x^{n} y^{n}
\end{aligned}
$$

so $x^{n} y^{n}$ is an integer. Substituting $(n+1)$ for $n$ in the above equality, we get that $a_{n+2}^{2}-a_{n+3} a_{n+1}=x^{n+1} y^{n+1}$ is also an integer; thus $x y=\frac{x^{n+1} y^{n+1}}{x^{n} y^{n}}$ (or 0) is a rational number. Since the $n$-th power of this rational number is an integer, it is only possible if $x y$ is also an integer.

If $x y=0$, then for example, if $y=0$, $a_{n}=x^{n-1}, a_{n+1}=x^{n}$ are integers, so $x$ is rational, and therefore (as the $n$-th root of an integer) is an integer; thus for all $k$, $a_{k}=x^{k-1}$ is also an integer. (Similarly, we can proceed if $x=0$.) In the following, we can assume that $x y \neq 0$. As we have seen, $x^{n} y^{n}(x+y)$ is an integer, so $x+y$ is rational. Suppose that $x+y$ is not an integer, i.e., $x+y=\frac{p}{q}$, where $p$ and $q$ are relatively prime integers and $q \geq 2$. Then $\left(a_{1}=1\right.$ and) $a_{2}=x+y=\frac{p}{q}$,

$$
a_{3}=\frac{x^{3}-y^{3}}{x-y}=x^{2}+x y+y^{2}=(x+y)^{2}-x y=\frac{p^{2}}{q^{2}}-x y=\frac{p^{2}-q^{2} x y}{q^{2}}
$$

where $p^{2}-q^{2} x y$ and $q^{2}$ are also relatively prime. By induction on $k$, we show that for every positive integer $k$, $a_{k}=\frac{p_{k}}{q^{k}}$, where $p_{k}$ is an integer relatively prime to $q^{k}$. Indeed, if $a_{k-2}=\frac{p_{k-2}}{q^{k-2}}$ and $a_{k-1}=\frac{p_{k-1}}{q^{k-1}}$, then

$$
a_{k}=(x+y) a_{k-1}-x y a_{k-2}=\frac{p p_{k-1}}{q^{k}}-x y \frac{p_{k-2}}{q^{k-2}}=\frac{p p_{k-1}-x y q^{2} p_{k-2}}{q^{k}}
$$

Here, $p$ and $p_{k-1}$ are relatively prime to $q$, and adding the $q$-divisible $x y q^{2} p_{k-2}$ to their product again yields a number relatively prime to $q$ (and thus to $q^{k}$). Applying the obtained result for $k=n$, we have $a_{n}=\frac{p_{n}}{q^{n}}$, contradicting the fact that $a_{n}$ is an integer. Therefore, $x+y$ is also an integer.

Benedek Valk√≥ (Fazekas M. F√≥v. Gyak. Gimn., IV. o.t.)
informal_statement: Let $x$ and $y$ be real numbers such that $\frac{x^{n}-y^{n}}{x-y}$ is an integer for four consecutive positive integers $n$. Then the same holds for all positive integers $n$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Let $x$ and $y$ be real numbers such that $\frac{x^{n}-y^{n}}{x-y}$ is an integer for four consecutive positive integers $n$. Then the same holds for all positive integers $n$. -/
theorem number_theory_202514 (x y : ‚Ñù) (h : ‚àÉ n : ‚Ñï, n > 0 ‚àß 
    ‚àÄ m ‚àà Finset.Icc n (n + 3), ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, (x ^ m - y ^ m) / (x - y) = k) :
    ‚àÄ n : ‚Ñï, n > 0 ‚Üí ‚àÉ k : ‚Ñ§, (x ^ n - y ^ n) / (x - y) = k := by

informal_statement: Let $u,$ $v,$ $w$ be the roots of $z^3 = 1.$  Find $uv + uw + vw.$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Polynomial

theorem calculus_22298 (u v w : ‚ÑÇ) (hroots : (X ^ 3 - 1 : ‚ÑÇ[X]).roots = {u, v, w}) :
    u * v + u * w + v * w = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Polynomial

theorem calculus_22298 (u v w : ‚ÑÇ) (hroots : (X ^ 3 - 1 : ‚ÑÇ[X]).roots = {u, v, w}) :
    u * v + u * w + v * w = 0 := by
  -- Set p := X^3 - 1 be the complex polynomial.
  set p : ‚ÑÇ[X] := X ^ 3 - 1 with hp
  -- The polynomial has degree 3.
  have hdeg : p.natDegree = 3 := by
    rw [hp]
    compute_degree!
  -- The polynomial has as many roots as its degree.
  have hcard : p.roots.card = p.natDegree := by
    rw [hp, hroots]
    simp [‚Üê hp, hdeg]
  -- The leading coefficient is 1.
  have hcoeff : p.leadingCoeff = 1 := by
    rw [hp, ‚Üê coeff_natDegree, hdeg]
    simp [coeff_one]
  -- Use Vieta's formula for the coefficient of X.
  -- We have uv + uw + vw = 0.
  have H := coeff_eq_esymm_roots_of_card hcard (k := 1) (by simp [hdeg])
  simp [hcoeff, hdeg, hroots, Multiset.esymm, Multiset.powersetCard_one] at H
  -- Simplify the expression and we are done.
  simp [hp, coeff_one] at H
  linear_combination -H

informal_statement: What is the sum of all numbers between 0 and 511 inclusive that have an even number of 1 s when written in binary?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_608730 : ‚àë·∂† i ‚àà {n : ‚Ñï | n ‚â§ 511 ‚àß Even ((Nat.digits 2 n).count 1)}, i = 65408 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_608730 : ‚àë·∂† i ‚àà {n : ‚Ñï | n ‚â§ 511 ‚àß Even ((Nat.digits 2 n).count 1)}, i = 65408 := by
  have h‚ÇÅ : {n : ‚Ñï | n ‚â§ 511 ‚àß Even ((Nat.digits 2 n).count 1)} = Finset.filter (Œªn ‚Ü¶ (Nat.digits 2 n).count 1 % 2 = 0) (Finset.Icc 0 511) := by
    ext n; simp
    rw [Nat.even_iff]
    tauto
  have h‚ÇÇ : ‚àë·∂† (i : ‚Ñï) (_ : i ‚àà ‚Üë(Finset.filter (fun n ‚Ü¶ List.count 1 (Nat.digits 2 n) % 2 = 0) (Finset.Icc 0 511) : Set ‚Ñï)), i = ‚àë i ‚àà Finset.filter (Œªn ‚Ü¶ (Nat.digits 2 n).count 1 % 2 = 0) (Finset.Icc 0 511), i := by
    apply finsum_mem_finset_eq_sum
  rw [h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ]
  native_decide

soln_description:
I. Solution. The expressions under the square root signs are always positive, since $3 x^{2}+2 x+1>3(x+1 / 3)^{2}$ and $3 x^{2}-4 x+2>3(x-2 / 3)^{2}$. Therefore, the left side is defined for all $x$. Since both sides of the inequality are positive, the inequality

$$
\sqrt{\left(3 x^{2}+2 x+1\right)\left(3 x^{2}-4 x+2\right)} \geqq-3 x^{2}+x+4 / 3
$$

holds precisely when the original one does. (2) The right side can be negative - in which case the inequality holds - and can also be non-negative, in which case we square it. After rearranging, the result is $(6 x-1)^{2} \geqq 0$. This always holds, which means that the original inequality holds for all $x$. (I. S.)

II. Solution. Consider the points $P(-1 / 3 ; \sqrt{2} / 3)$ and $Q(2 / 3 ;-\sqrt{2} / 3)$ in a Cartesian coordinate system. For any point $X(x ; 0)$ on the $x$-axis, the squares of the distances from $P$ and $Q$ are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& P X^{2}=\left(x+\frac{1}{3}\right)^{2}+\frac{2}{9}=\frac{1}{3}\left(3 x^{2}+2 x+1\right) \\
& Q X^{2}=\left(x-\frac{2}{3}\right)^{2}+\frac{2}{9}=\frac{1}{3}\left(3 x^{2}-4 x+2\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

By the triangle inequality, $P X+Q X \geqq P Q, \mathrm{~s}$ and since $P Q=\sqrt{17} / 3$, this precisely gives the inequality to be proven. Equality holds when $X$ is the intersection of the segment $P Q$ and the $x$-axis, i.e., when $x=1 / 6$.
informal_statement:
We will prove that the following inequality holds for all $x$:

$$
\sqrt{3 x^{2}+2 x+1}+\sqrt{3 x^{2}-4 x+2} \geq \sqrt{51} / 3
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- We will prove that the following inequality holds for all $x$:

$$
\sqrt{3 x^{2}+2 x+1}+\sqrt{3 x^{2}-4 x+2} \geq \sqrt{51} / 3
$$ -/
theorem inequalities_201318 (x : ‚Ñù) :
    Real.sqrt (3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1) + Real.sqrt (3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2) ‚â•
    Real.sqrt 51 / 3 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_201318 (x : ‚Ñù) :
    Real.sqrt (3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1) + Real.sqrt (3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2) ‚â•
    Real.sqrt 51 / 3 := by 
  set y := Real.sqrt (3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1)
  set z := Real.sqrt (3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2)
  have hy2 : y^2 = 3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1 := by
    rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x + 1 / 3)]
  have hz2 : z^2 = 3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2 := by 
    rw [Real.sq_sqrt]
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 2 / 3)]
  have hy4_pos : 0 ‚â§ (3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1 : ‚Ñù) := by 
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * 3 + 1)]
  have hz4_pos : 0 ‚â§ (3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2 : ‚Ñù) := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x * 3 - 2)]
  have h11 : (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ^ 2 = (51 / 9 : ‚Ñù) := by
    calc
      (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ^ 2 = (Real.sqrt 51) ^ 2 / 9 := by ring
      _ = (51 / 9 : ‚Ñù) := by 
        rw [Real.sq_sqrt (by norm_num)]
        <;> ring
  have h50 : (y + z) ^ 2 ‚â• (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ^ 2 := by
    nlinarith [sq_nonneg (y - z), sq_nonneg (x - 2 / 3), sq_nonneg (x + 1 / 3),
      h11, Real.sqrt_nonneg 51, Real.sq_sqrt (show 0 ‚â§ (51 : ‚Ñù) by norm_num), 
      mul_nonneg (Real.sqrt_nonneg (3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1)) (Real.sqrt_nonneg (3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2)), 
      sq_nonneg (y ^ 2 - z ^ 2), sq_nonneg (y * z - Real.sqrt ((3 * x^2 + 2 * x + 1) * (3 * x^2 - 4 * x + 2)))
      ]
  have h51 : (y + z) ‚â• 0 := by positivity
  have h54 : (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ‚â• 0 := by positivity
  have h52 : (y + z) ‚â• (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) := by
    have h15 : (y + z) ^ 2 ‚â• (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ^ 2 := h50
    have h16 : (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ‚â• 0 := h54
    have h17 : (y + z) - (Real.sqrt 51 / 3) ‚â• 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg ((y + z) - (Real.sqrt 51 / 3)), 
        sq_nonneg ((y + z) + (Real.sqrt 51 / 3)), 
        Real.sqrt_pos.mpr (show (0 : ‚Ñù) < 51 by linarith : (51 : ‚Ñù) > 0)
        ]
    linarith
  linarith

informal_statement: Find $(\log_2 x)^2$ if $\log_2 (\log_8 x) = \log_8 (\log_2 x).$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Find $(\log_2 x)^2$ if $\log_2 (\log_8 x) = \log_8 (\log_2 x).$ -/
theorem algebra_21388 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 1) (h : logb 2 (logb 8 x) = logb 8 (logb 2 x)) :
    (logb 2 x)^2 = 27 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Find $(\log_2 x)^2$ if $\log_2 (\log_8 x) = \log_8 (\log_2 x).$ -/
theorem algebra_21388 {x : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 1) (h : logb 2 (logb 8 x) = logb 8 (logb 2 x)) :
    (logb 2 x)^2 = 27 := by
  -- We first show that logb 2 x is positive.
  have h‚ÇÄ : 0 < logb 2 x := logb_pos (by simp) hx
  -- We then show that logb 8 z = logb 2 z / 3 for all z.
  have lem (x : ‚Ñù) : logb 8 x = logb 2 x / 3 := by
    have h := Real.mul_logb (a := 2) (b := 8) (c := x)
    norm_num at h
    have h' : logb 2 8 = 3 := (logb_eq_iff_rpow_eq (by simp) (by simp) (by simp)).mpr (by norm_num)
    simp [‚Üê h, h']
  -- We use the lemma to rewrite the given equation.
  rw [lem, lem] at h
  cancel_denoms at h
  -- Rewrite 3 * logb 2 z as logb 2 (z ^ 3).
  nth_rw 1 [show (3 : ‚Ñù) = (3 : ‚Ñï) by simp, ‚Üê Real.logb_pow] at h
  -- Take the power of 2 on both sides.
  apply_fun ((2 : ‚Ñù) ^ ¬∑) at h
  -- Cancel 2 ^ logb 2 z on both sides.
  iterate 2 rw [Real.rpow_logb (by simp) (by simp) (by positivity)] at h
  -- Simple algebra.
  rw [show (logb 2 x / 3) ^ 3 = logb 2 x ^ 2 / 27 * logb 2 x by ring] at h
  simpa [ne_of_gt h‚ÇÄ, div_eq_one_iff_eq] using h

soln_description:
I. The right-hand side segmented decimal fractions in the solution of problem 1302 are converted into the ratios of two natural numbers $A / B$ and $C / D$, similar to the procedure seen in 1 1. The seventh decimal place of the first segmented decimal fraction marks the beginning of the infinite repetition of the 538461 segment. This is a consequence of the fact that when determining the digits of the $A: B$ ratio up to 6.6538461 (and already subtracting the partial product of 1 with $B$ from the partial dividend), the same remainder $R$ reappeared as it did after determining the digits of the ratio up to 6.6, except that in the latter case, the local value of $R$ is $1 / 10$, while in the case of repetition, it is $1 / 10000000 = 1 / 10^{7}$. Thus, the two remainder divisions yield the following expressions for the next representation of $A$:

$$
A = B \cdot 6.6 + R / 10
$$

$$
\text{or} \quad A = B \cdot 6.6538461 + R / 10^{7}
$$

Subtracting the first equality from the second, multiplied by $10^{6}$, gives the desired form:

$\left(10^{6}-1\right) A = B(6653846.1 - 6.6)$,

$$
\frac{A}{B} = \frac{66538461 - 66}{10 \cdot (10^{6} - 1)} = \frac{66538395}{9999990} = \frac{173}{26}
$$

In the simplification, we used the fact that the denominator can be easily factored:

$$
999999 = 999 \cdot 1001, \quad 999 = 27 \cdot 37, \quad \text{and} \quad 1001 = 7 \cdot 11 \cdot 13
$$

Thus, the first segmented decimal fraction can be converted to the common fraction 173/26, which can be easily verified.

Similarly, the common fraction form of the right-hand side of equation (2) is

$$
\frac{C}{D} = \frac{5769230 - 5}{9999990} = \frac{15}{26}
$$

II. Multiply both equations by $x y$, and add $2 x y$ to the new first equation, so that the left side of the final form is equal to the square of the left side of the new second equation:

$$
\begin{gathered}
x^{2} + y^{2} = \frac{173}{26} x y \\
x + y = \frac{15}{26} x y \\
x^{2} + 2 x y + y^{2} = (x + y)^{2} = \left(\frac{173}{26} + 2\right) x y = \frac{225}{26} x y
\end{gathered}
$$

Thus, dividing (1b) by (2a) and then the square of (2a) by (1b), and rearranging, we get

$$
x + y = 15, \quad x y = 26
$$

(We used the fact that $x \neq 0$ and $y \neq 0$, otherwise the system of equations would have no meaning.) Therefore, $x$ and $y$ are equal to the roots of the equation

$$
z^{2} - 15 z + 26 = 0
$$

which are 13 and 2, in any order:

$$
x_{1} = 13, \quad y_{1} = 2, \quad \text{and} \quad x_{2} = y_{1}, \quad y_{2} = x_{1}
$$

The value pair indeed satisfies the system of equations.

Steiner Gy√∂rgy (Budapest, Radn√≥ti M. gyak. g. III. o. t.) Baranyai Zsolt (Budapest, Fazekas M. gyak. g. III. o. t.)

Remarks. 1. By introducing a new variable $u$ for $x / y$, after converting the infinite decimal fractions to common fractions, we arrive at the system of equations

$$
u + \frac{1}{u} = \frac{173}{26}, \quad \frac{1}{y}\left(\frac{1}{u} + 1\right) = \frac{15}{26}, \quad x = y u
$$

From the first, $u$ is 13/2 and 2/13, from the second, $y$ is 2 and 13, and from the third, $x$ is 13 and 2.

Varga Gabriella (Szombathely, Savaria g. II. o. t.)

2. Most of the solutions chose the method of converting the segmented decimal fractions to common fractions, which, as mentioned in the second remark of problem 1302, proceeds in a way not clarified in the high school curriculum, performing subtraction with numbers written with infinitely many digits as if they were written with finitely many digits. Those who converted the fractions in the manner described above or mentioned this issue received 1 bonus point.[^0]

[^0]: ${ }^{1}$ The editorial board recommended studying the solution of problem 1302 when this exercise was assigned; see K. M. L. 30 (1965) 18. o.
informal_statement:
Solve the following system of equations:
(1) $\quad x / y+y / x=6,6 \dot{5} 3846 \dot{1}$,
(2) $\quad 1 / x+1 / y=0,5 \dot{7} 6923 \dot{0}$.

(The numbers on the right side are repeating decimals. Read the solution to problem 1302, then convert the numbers on the right side to common fractions.)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following system of equations:
(1) $\quad x / y+y / x=6,6 \dot{5} 3846 \dot{1}$,
(2) $\quad 1 / x+1 / y=0,5 \dot{7} 6923 \dot{0}$.

(The numbers on the right side are repeating decimals. Read the solution to problem 1302, then convert the numbers on the right side to common fractions.) -/
theorem algebra_201348 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0) :
    x / y + y / x = 66/10 + 538461/9999990 ‚àß 1 / x + 1 / y = 1/2 + 769230/9999990 ‚Üî (x = 13 ‚àß y = 2) ‚à® (x = 2 ‚àß y = 13) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_201348 {x y : ‚Ñù} (hx : x ‚â† 0) (hy : y ‚â† 0) :
    x / y + y / x = 66/10 + 538461/9999990 ‚àß 1 / x + 1 / y = 1/2 + 769230/9999990 ‚Üî (x = 13 ‚àß y = 2) ‚à® (x = 2 ‚àß y = 13) := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Forward implication: If the equations hold, then (x=13,y=2) or (x=2,y=13).
    intro ‚ü®h1, h2‚ü©
    have eq3 : x^2 + y^2 = (66 / 10 + 538461 / 9999990) * (x * y) := by
      field_simp [hy, hx] at h1 ‚ä¢
      nlinarith
    have eq4 : x + y = (1/2 + 769230 / 9999990) * (x * y) := by
      field_simp [hy, hx] at h2 ‚ä¢
      nlinarith

    have eq6 : (x - 13) * (x - 2) = 0 := by
      nlinarith [sq_pos_of_ne_zero hx, sq_pos_of_ne_zero hy, sq_nonneg (x - y), sq_nonneg (x + y - 0)]
    cases' (mul_eq_zero.1 eq6) with h7 h8
    ¬∑ -- Case x = 13
      have hx13 : x = 13 := by linarith
      have hy2 : y = 2 := by
        nlinarith [hx13, h2]
      left
      exact ‚ü®hx13, hy2‚ü©
    ¬∑ -- Case x = 2
      have hx2 : x = 2 := by linarith
      have hy13 : y = 13 := by
        nlinarith [hx2, h2]
      right
      exact ‚ü®hx2, hy13‚ü©
  ¬∑ -- Backward implication: given the solutions, prove the equations.
    rintro (h | h)
    ¬∑ -- First solution (x = 13, y = 2)
      rw [h.1, h.2]
      constructor <;> norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Second solution (x = 2, y = 13)
      rw [h.1, h.2]
      constructor <;> norm_num

informal_statement: Chris labels every lattice point in the coordinate plane with the square of the distance from the point to the origin (a lattice point is a point such that both of its coordinates are integers). How many times does he label a point with the number $25$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Chris labels every lattice point in the coordinate plane with the square of the distance from the point to the origin (a lattice point is a point such that both of its coordinates are integers). How many times does he label a point with the number $25$? -/
theorem algebra_22154 : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^2 + y^2 = 25}.ncard = 12 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Chris labels every lattice point in the coordinate plane with the square of the distance from the point to the origin (a lattice point is a point such that both of its coordinates are integers). How many times does he label a point with the number $25$? -/
theorem algebra_22154 : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^2 + y^2 = 25}.ncard = 12 := by
  -- It suffices to find out all the lattice points that satisfy x^2 + y^2 = 25
  suffices H : {(x, y) : ‚Ñ§ √ó ‚Ñ§ | x^2 + y^2 = 25} = {(-3, -4), (-3, 4), (-4, -3), (-4, 3), (3, -4), (3, 4), (4, -3), (4, 3), (-5, 0), (5, 0), (0, -5), (0, 5)} by
    rw [H, ‚Üê Set.coe_toFinset {(-3, -4), (-3, 4), (-4, -3), (-4, 3), (3, -4), (3, 4), (4, -3), (4, 3), (-5, 0), (5, 0), (0, -5), (0, 5)}, Set.ncard_coe_Finset]
    simp

  -- We prove mutual inclusion
  ext ‚ü®x, y‚ü©
  simp
  constructor
  . -- First inclusion
    intro h
    -- We have -5 ‚â§ x ‚â§ 5
    have hx1 : x ‚â• -5 := by nlinarith
    have hx2 : x ‚â§ 5 := by nlinarith
    -- Case analysis on x
    interval_cases x
    all_goals
      clear x hx1 hx2
      simp
      norm_num at h
      -- Two goals are trivial
      try
        trivial
      -- Five goals are the form of y = -n ‚à® y = n
      try
        rw [Or.comm]
        apply eq_or_eq_neg_of_sq_eq_sq
        linarith
    -- Four goals remain, they are the form: h : a + y^2 = 25, and we need to prove False
    all_goals
        -- Get the value of y^2
        apply eq_sub_of_add_eq' at h
        norm_num at h
        have H : IsSquare (y^2) := ‚ü®y, pow_two y‚ü©
        rw [h] at H
        -- But the value of y^2 is not a perfect square, contradiction
        absurd H
        -- The use of native_decide here can be replaced by hand calculation
        native_decide

  . -- Second inclusion
    -- We check all the cases
    rintro (‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü© | ‚ü®rfl, rfl‚ü©)
    all_goals
      simp

informal_statement: The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: $F_{0}=0, F_{1}=1$, and $F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2}$ for all integers $n \geq 2$. Find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_{m} \equiv 0(\bmod 127)$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1(\bmod 127)$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: $F_{0}=0, F_{1}=1$, and $F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2}$ for all integers $n \geq 2$. Find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_{m} \equiv 0(\bmod 127)$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1(\bmod 127)$. -/
theorem number_theory_609646 :
    IsLeast {m | 0 < m ‚àß Nat.fib m ‚â° 0 [MOD 127] ‚àß Nat.fib (m + 1) ‚â° 1 [MOD 127]} 256 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- The Fibonacci sequence is defined as follows: $F_{0}=0, F_{1}=1$, and $F_{n}=F_{n-1}+F_{n-2}$ for all integers $n \geq 2$. Find the smallest positive integer $m$ such that $F_{m} \equiv 0(\bmod 127)$ and $F_{m+1} \equiv 1(\bmod 127)$. -/
theorem number_theory_609646 :
    IsLeast {m | 0 < m ‚àß Nat.fib m ‚â° 0 [MOD 127] ‚àß Nat.fib (m + 1) ‚â° 1 [MOD 127]} 256 := by
  constructor
  . -- Let's compute fib 256 and fib 257
    norm_num
    -- Calculate their values modulo 127
    decide
  . -- We show that 256 is the smallest such number
    intro m ‚ü®h‚ÇÅ, h‚ÇÇ, h‚ÇÉ‚ü©
    -- We can prove that any m < 256 is not a solution by brute force
    by_contra! h‚ÇÑ
    revert h‚ÇÅ h‚ÇÇ h‚ÇÉ
    revert m
    native_decide

soln_description:
To solve the equation, it is necessary to observe that the two terms on the left side are reciprocals of each other. This is true because

$$
(\sqrt{5}+2) \cdot(\sqrt{5}-2)=(\sqrt{5})^{2}-2^{2}=1
$$

Let $y=(\sqrt{5}+2)^{x}$. Based on the above, $(\sqrt{5}-2)^{x}=\frac{1}{y}$. Substituting these into the equation:

$$
y+\frac{1}{y}=18
$$

Multiplying by $y$ and rearranging, we get the quadratic equation $y^{2}-18 y+1=0$, which has two solutions: $9+\sqrt{80}$ and $9-\sqrt{80}$, which are also reciprocals of each other.

It is easily verifiable that

$$
9+\sqrt{80}=(\sqrt{5}+2)^{2} \quad \text { and } \quad 9-\sqrt{80}=(\sqrt{5}-2)^{2}=(\sqrt{5}+2)^{-2}
$$

Since neither base is 1, it follows from these that the equation is satisfied only by $x=2$ and $x=-2$. The reversibility of our steps also confirms that these are indeed solutions.

Thus, the equation has two solutions: $x_{1}=2$ and $x_{2}=-2$.
informal_statement:
Solve the following equation in the set of real numbers:

$$
(\sqrt{5}+2)^{x}+(\sqrt{5}-2)^{x}=18
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following equation in the set of real numbers:

$$
(\sqrt{5}+2)^{x}+(\sqrt{5}-2)^{x}=18
$$ -/
theorem algebra_203298 (x : ‚Ñù) :
    (Real.sqrt 5 + 2)^x + (Real.sqrt 5 - 2)^x = 18 ‚Üî x = 2 ‚à® x = -2 := by

informal_statement:
Let $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} -11 \\ 5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 + \sqrt{5} \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $k$ if the vectors $\mathbf{a} + \mathbf{b} + \mathbf{c}$ and
\[3 (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) - 8 (\mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a}) + k (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b})\]are orthogonal.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real
open scoped BigOperators

/- Let $\mathbf{a} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 \\ 3 \\ 0 \end{pmatrix},$ $\mathbf{b} = \begin{pmatrix} -11 \\ 5 \\ 2 \end{pmatrix},$ and $\mathbf{c} = \begin{pmatrix} 1 + \sqrt{5} \\ 4 \\ -5 \end{pmatrix}.$  Find $k$ if the vectors $\mathbf{a} + \mathbf{b} + \mathbf{c}$ and
\[3 (\mathbf{b} \times \mathbf{c}) - 8 (\mathbf{c} \times \mathbf{a}) + k (\mathbf{a} \times \mathbf{b})\]are orthogonal. -/
theorem calculus_22016
  (a b c : Fin 3 ‚Üí ‚Ñù)
  (ha : a = ![1, 3, 0])
  (hb : b = ![-11, 5, 2])
  (hc : c = ![1 + sqrt 5, 4, -5]) :
  (a + b + c) ‚Ä¢ (3 * (crossProduct b c) - 8 * (crossProduct c a) +
    k * (crossProduct a b)) = 0 ‚Üî k = 5 := by

soln_description:
Consider the sum up to $\frac{1}{a_{m}}$ in general. By definition, $a_{n}=k$ if $k-\frac{1}{2}0$, so

$$
x_{0}=\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}
$$

and $p \leq x_{0}<p+1$ implies

$$
p=\left[x_{0}\right]=\left[\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}\right]
$$

The sum of the reciprocals can then be written as follows:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\underbrace{2+2+\cdots+2}_{p \text { terms }}+\underbrace{\frac{1}{p+1}+\cdots+\frac{1}{p+1}}_{m-2(1+2+\cdots+p)=m-p(p+1)}=2 p+\frac{m}{p+1}-\frac{p(p+1)}{p+1}= \\
=p+\frac{m}{p+1}=\left[\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}\right]+\frac{m}{\left[\frac{-1+\sqrt{4 m-3}}{2}\right]+1}
\end{gathered}
$$

For the case $m=1994$, the sum is $\frac{3974}{45}$.

Based on the work of Gyula Pap (Debrecen, Fazekas M. Gymnasium, 1st year)
informal_statement:
Let $a_{n}$ denote the integer closest to $\sqrt{n}$. What is the value of

$$
\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{1994}}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Let $a_{n}$ denote the integer closest to $\sqrt{n}$. What is the value of

$$
\frac{1}{a_{1}}+\frac{1}{a_{2}}+\cdots+\frac{1}{a_{1994}}
$$ -/
theorem number_theory_203328 (a : ‚Ñï ‚Üí ‚Ñ§) (ha : ‚àÄ n, a n = round (sqrt n)) :
    ‚àë i in Finset.range 1994, ((1 : ‚Ñö) / a (i + 1)) = 3974 / 45 := by

informal_statement: A parabola with equation $y=ax^2+bx+c$ has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ and goes through the two points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$. The quadratic $ax^2 + bx +c$  has two real roots. The greater root is $\sqrt{n}+2$. What is $n$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A parabola with equation $y=ax^2+bx+c$ has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ and goes through the two points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$. The quadratic $ax^2 + bx +c$  has two real roots. The greater root is $\sqrt{n}+2$. What is $n$? -/
theorem algebra_22113 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àÄ x, a * (4 - x) ^ 2 + b * (4 - x) + c = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (h1 : a * 1 ^ 2 + b * 1 + c = 1) (h2 : a * 4 ^ 2 + b * 4 + c = -1)
    (x1 x2 : ‚Ñù)
    (root1: x1 > x2)
    (root2: a * x1 ^ 2 + b * x1 + c = 0 ‚àß a * x2 ^ 2 + b * x2 + c = 0)
    (n: ‚Ñù)
    (root3: x1 = Real.sqrt n + 2) : n = 5 / 2 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- A parabola with equation $y=ax^2+bx+c$ has a vertical line of symmetry at $x=2$ and goes through the two points $(1,1)$ and $(4,-1)$. The quadratic $ax^2 + bx +c$  has two real roots. The greater root is $\sqrt{n}+2$. What is $n$? -/
theorem algebra_22113 {a b c : ‚Ñù} (ha : a ‚â† 0) (h : ‚àÄ x, a * (4 - x) ^ 2 + b * (4 - x) + c = a * x ^ 2 + b * x + c)
    (h1 : a * 1 ^ 2 + b * 1 + c = 1) (h2 : a * 4 ^ 2 + b * 4 + c = -1)
    (x1 x2 : ‚Ñù)
    (root1: x1 > x2)
    (root2: a * x1 ^ 2 + b * x1 + c = 0 ‚àß a * x2 ^ 2 + b * x2 + c = 0)
    (n: ‚Ñù)
    (root3: x1 = Real.sqrt n + 2) : n = 5 / 2 := by
  simp at *
  -- solve a, b, c
  have h3 : -4 * a = b := by
    specialize h 0
    linarith
  rw [<- h3] at h1
  rw [<- h3] at h2
  ring_nf at h2
  rw [h2] at h1
  ring_nf at h1
  have h1 : a = -2/3 := by linarith
  rw [h1] at h3
  ring_nf at h3

  -- solve x1, x2
  have disc: discrim a b c = 40/9 := by
    rw [h1, <- h3, h2]
    unfold discrim
    ring_nf
  let s := (Real.sqrt 40) / 3
  have s2 : discrim a b c = s * s := by
    rw [disc]
    ring_nf
    simp
    ring_nf

  -- solve x1
  have x1p: a * (x1 * x1) + b * x1 + c = 0 := by rw [<- root2.1]; ring_nf
  rw [(quadratic_eq_zero_iff ha s2 x1), h1, <- h3] at x1p
  ring_nf at x1p

  -- solve x2
  have x2p: a * (x2 * x2) + b * x2 + c = 0 := by rw [<- root2.2]; ring_nf
  rw [(quadratic_eq_zero_iff ha s2 x2), h1, <- h3] at x2p
  ring_nf at x2p

  -- use x1 > x2
  match x1p with
  | Or.inl h => {
    -- x1 is the smaller root
    match x2p with
    | Or.inl h' => {
      -- x1, x2 is the smaller root
      linarith
    }
    | Or.inr h' => {
      -- x2 is the larger root
      -- x2 > x1
      rw [h, h'] at root1
      simp at root1
      ring_nf at root1
      linarith
    }
  }
  | Or.inr h => {
    -- x1 is the larger root
    match x2p with
    | Or.inl h' => {
      rw [h] at root3
      ring_nf at root3
      simp at root3

      have n_pos : 0 < n := by rw [<- Real.sqrt_pos, <- root3]; simp
      have n_pos : 0 ‚â§ n := le_of_lt n_pos
      rw [<- Real.sq_sqrt n_pos, <- root3]
      ring_nf
      simp
      ring_nf
    }
    | Or.inr h' => {
      -- x1, x2 is the larger root
      linarith
    }
  }

soln_description:
Evaluate the product of the digits, replacing each digit, except the first, with ten.

## Solution

Let the number $\mathrm{N}$ be represented in decimal notation by the digits $\mathrm{a}_{0}, \mathrm{a}_{1}, \mathrm{a}_{2}, \ldots, \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{n}}, \mathrm{n}>0$. Then the product of the digits of the number $\mathrm{N}$ is $\mathrm{P}=\mathrm{a}_{0} \mathrm{a}_{1} \mathrm{a}_{2} \ldots \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{n}}$, which is less than $\mathrm{a}_{0} * 10^{\mathrm{n}}$, since each of the digits $\mathrm{a}_{1}, \mathrm{a}_{2}, \ldots, \mathrm{a}_{\mathrm{n}}$ is less than 10. The number $\mathrm{a}_{0} * 10^{\mathrm{n}}$ has in its decimal representation the digit $\mathrm{a}_{0}$ followed by $\mathrm{n}$ zeros. Therefore, $\mathrm{a}_{0} * 10^{\mathrm{n}}$ is not greater than $\mathrm{N}$.

Submit a comment
informal_statement:
[ Decimal numeral system ]

Prove that the product of the digits of any natural number greater than 9 is less than the number itself.

#
formal_statement:
import Mathlib


/- [ Decimal numeral system ]

Prove that the product of the digits of any natural number greater than 9 is less than the number itself.

# -/
theorem number_theory_202501:
  ‚àÄ(n:‚Ñï), n > 9 ‚Üí (Nat.digits 10 n).prod < n := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib


/- [ Decimal numeral system ]

Prove that the product of the digits of any natural number greater than 9 is less than the number itself.

# -/
theorem number_theory_202501:
  ‚àÄ(n:‚Ñï), n > 9 ‚Üí (Nat.digits 10 n).prod < n := by
  intro n hn
  -- n ‚â• 10, digit length ‚â• 2.
  have h1: (Nat.digits 10 n).length ‚â• 2 := by
    by_contra!
    replace: (Nat.digits 10 n).length ‚â§ 1 := Nat.le_of_lt_succ this
    replace hn: n ‚â• 10 := by exact hn
    have h: n < 10^(Nat.digits 10 n).length := by
      exact Nat.lt_base_pow_length_digits'
    absurd hn
    push_neg
    apply lt_of_lt_of_le h ?_
    nth_rw 3 [‚Üê pow_one 10]
    apply (Nat.pow_le_pow_iff_right (by norm_num)).mpr this

  have h1': Nat.digits 10 n ‚â† [] := by
    refine List.ne_nil_of_length_pos ?_
    omega
  obtain ‚ü®k, kpos, hk‚ü©: ‚àÉ (k: Fin (Nat.digits 10 n).length),
    ‚ü®0, (by omega)‚ü© < k ‚àß
    (Nat.digits 10 n).length = k + 1 := by
    use ‚ü®(Nat.digits 10 n).length - 1, (by omega)‚ü©
    simp only [Nat.reduceLeDiff, Fin.mk_lt_mk, tsub_pos_iff_lt]
    omega
  have keq: (k:‚Ñï) = (Nat.digits 10 n).length - 1 := by
    omega

  -- single out most significant digit
  have h2: (Nat.digits 10 n) = (Nat.digits 10 n).take (k + 1) := by
    rw [‚Üê hk, List.take_length]
  rw [h2, List.prod_take_succ _ _ k.is_lt]

  -- product of remaining digits ‚â§ 9^k
  have h3: ((Nat.digits 10 n).take k).prod ‚â§ 9^(k:‚Ñï) := by
    nth_rw 2 [‚Üê List.length_take_of_le k.is_le']
    apply List.prod_le_pow_card
    intro i hi
    replace hi: i ‚àà Nat.digits 10 n := List.mem_of_mem_take hi
    suffices i < 10 by exact Nat.le_of_lt_succ this
    exact Nat.digits_lt_base' hi
  replace h3: ((Nat.digits 10 n).take k).prod < 10^(k:‚Ñï) := by
    refine lt_of_le_of_lt h3 ?_
    apply (Nat.pow_lt_pow_iff_left ?_).mpr (by norm_num)
    exact Nat.not_eq_zero_of_lt kpos
  replace h3: ((Nat.digits 10 n).take k).prod *
    (Nat.digits 10 n)[k] < 10^(k:‚Ñï) * (Nat.digits 10 n)[k] := by
    refine Nat.mul_lt_mul_of_pos_right h3 ?_
    simp only [Nat.reduceLeDiff, Fin.getElem_fin,
    gt_iff_lt, keq]
    rw [List.getElem_length_sub_one_eq_getLast]
    refine Nat.zero_lt_of_ne_zero ?_
    refine Nat.getLast_digit_ne_zero 10 (by omega)

  -- and 10^k multiply most siginificant digit ‚â§ n
  have h4: 10^(k:‚Ñï) * (Nat.digits 10 n)[k] ‚â§ n := by
    rw [mul_comm (10^(k:‚Ñï)) _, ‚Üê Nat.le_div_iff_mul_le (by simp),
    Nat.self_div_pow_eq_ofDigits_drop _ _ (by norm_num)]
    rw [keq, List.drop_length_sub_one h1',
    ‚Üê List.get_length_sub_one (by omega)]
    simp [keq]

  -- done.
  exact lt_of_lt_of_le h3 h4

informal_statement: Given that the two roots of the quadratic equation ${{x}^{2}}+mx+2520=0$ are positive integers, find the maximum possible value of $m$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

-- we write the simp form of vieta's formula as a lemma
lemma vieta_formula {p q x1 x2: ‚Ñù} (ne: x1 ‚â† x2) (h1: x1 ^ 2 + p * x1 + q = 0) (h2: x2 ^ 2 + p * x2 + q = 0):
    x1 + x2 = -p ‚àß x1 * x2 = q := by

  have h: (x1 - x2) * (x1 + x2 + p) = 0 := by nlinarith
  replace ne: ¬¨ x1 - x2 = 0 := by
    by_contra! i
    replace i: x1 = x2 := by linarith
    simp [i] at ne
  simp [ne] at h
  constructor
  .
    linarith
  .
    have f: (x1 + x2) ^ 2 - 2 * (x1 * x2) + p * (x1 + x2) + 2 * q = 0 := by
      nlinarith
    replace h: x1 + x2 = -p := by linarith
    simp [h] at f
    nlinarith

/-Given that the two roots of the quadratic equation
x^2 +mx+2520=0 are positive integers,
find the maximum possible value of m -/

theorem algebra_628897: IsGreatest {m: ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ a b: ‚Ñ§, 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß
  a ^ 2 + m * a + 2520 = 0 ‚àß b ^ 2 + m * b + 2520 = 0 ‚àß ‚àÄ y: ‚Ñù, y ^ 2 + m * y + 2520 = 0 ‚Üí y = a ‚à® y = b} (-101) := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

-- we write the simp form of vieta's formula as a lemma
lemma vieta_formula {p q x1 x2: ‚Ñù} (ne: x1 ‚â† x2) (h1: x1 ^ 2 + p * x1 + q = 0) (h2: x2 ^ 2 + p * x2 + q = 0):
    x1 + x2 = -p ‚àß x1 * x2 = q := by

  have h: (x1 - x2) * (x1 + x2 + p) = 0 := by nlinarith
  replace ne: ¬¨ x1 - x2 = 0 := by
    by_contra! i
    replace i: x1 = x2 := by linarith
    simp [i] at ne
  simp [ne] at h
  constructor
  .
    linarith
  .
    have f: (x1 + x2) ^ 2 - 2 * (x1 * x2) + p * (x1 + x2) + 2 * q = 0 := by
      nlinarith
    replace h: x1 + x2 = -p := by linarith
    simp [h] at f
    nlinarith

/-Given that the two roots of the quadratic equation
x^2 +mx+2520=0 are positive integers,
find the maximum possible value of m -/

theorem algebra_628897: IsGreatest {m: ‚Ñù | ‚àÉ a b: ‚Ñ§, 0 < a ‚àß 0 < b ‚àß
  a ^ 2 + m * a + 2520 = 0 ‚àß b ^ 2 + m * b + 2520 = 0 ‚àß ‚àÄ y: ‚Ñù, y ^ 2 + m * y + 2520 = 0 ‚Üí y = a ‚à® y = b} (-101) := by

    constructor

    -- the forward direction
    .
      simp
      use 45
      norm_num
      use 56
      norm_num
      intro y h
      rw [show y ^ 2 + -(101 * y) + 2520 = (y - 45) * (y - 56) by ring] at h
      simp at h
      rcases h with h | h
      .
        left
        linarith
      .
        right
        linarith

    -- the backward direction
    .
      intro m h
      simp only [Set.mem_setOf_eq] at h
      obtain ‚ü®a, b, la, lb, ha, hb, hy‚ü© := h
      by_cases l: a = b

      -- case1, multiple roots
      .
        simp [‚Üê l] at hy
        clear hb l lb
        set c:= -m - a -- we show that c is also a root
        specialize hy c
        have o: c ^ 2 + m * c + 2520 = 0 := by
          simp [c]
          nlinarith
        simp [o] at hy -- hence c = a
        simp [c] at hy
        replace hy: m = -2 * a := by nlinarith
        simp [hy] at ha
        ring_nf at ha
        norm_cast at ha
        have la1: 50 < a := by nlinarith
        have la2: a < 51 := by nlinarith
        omega

      -- case2, distinct roots
      .
        clear hy
        replace l: (a: ‚Ñù) ‚â† b := by
          by_contra! i
          simp at i
          simp [i] at l

        -- then we apply vieta's formula
        have f:= vieta_formula l ha hb
        rcases f with ‚ü®f, g‚ü©
        norm_cast at g
        have d: a ‚à£ 2520 := by
          rw [‚Üê g]
          simp

        -- for convenience, prove by contradction
        by_contra! i
        replace i: -m < 101 := by linarith
        rw [‚Üê f] at i
        clear f ha hb
        norm_cast at i
        by_cases r: a < b
        
        -- case a < b
        .
          have ra: a < 51 := by nlinarith
          have rb: b < 100 := by nlinarith
          replace la: 25 < a := by nlinarith

          -- then we check all value of a
          interval_cases a
          all_goals norm_num at d
          all_goals omega

        -- case a > b
        .
          simp at l
          replace r: b < a := by omega
          clear l
          have ra: a < 100 := by nlinarith
          have rb: b < 51 := by nlinarith
          replace lb: 25 < b := by nlinarith

          -- then we check all value of b
          interval_cases b
          all_goals norm_num at d
          all_goals omega

informal_statement: Suppose that $N$ can be written in base $6$ as $531340_6$ and in base $8$ as $124154_8$. In base $10$, what is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$?
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose that $N$ can be written in base $6$ as $531340_6$ and in base $8$ as $124154_8$. In base $10$, what is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$? -/
theorem number_theory_22865 {N : ‚Ñï} (hN6 : N = 5*6^5 + 3*6^4 + 1*6^3+3*6^2+4*6) (hN8 : N = 1*8^5+2*8^4+4*8^3+1*8^2+5*8+4) :
    N ‚â° 66 [MOD 210] := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

/- Suppose that $N$ can be written in base $6$ as $531340_6$ and in base $8$ as $124154_8$. In base $10$, what is the remainder when $N$ is divided by $210$? -/
theorem number_theory_22865 {N : ‚Ñï} (hN6 : N = 5*6^5 + 3*6^4 + 1*6^3+3*6^2+4*6) (hN8 : N = 1*8^5+2*8^4+4*8^3+1*8^2+5*8+4) :
    N ‚â° 66 [MOD 210] := by
  -- notice that 210 = 6x5x7. by chinese remainder theorem, it suffices to find N modulo 5,6,7. the last digit of N in base 6 is 0, so N module 6 is 0.
  have hm6: N ‚â° 0 [MOD 6] := by
    have: N = 6*(5*6^4+3*6^3+1*6^2+3*6+4) := by
      rw [hN6]; ring
    rw [this]
    apply Nat.modEq_zero_iff_dvd.mpr
    apply Nat.dvd_mul_right 6
  -- and a (p+1)^n mod p is a.
  have h1(a n p:‚Ñï): a*(p+1)^n ‚â° a [MOD p] := by
    have hh1: p+1 ‚â° 1 [MOD p] := by
      exact Nat.add_modEq_left
    have hh2: (p+1)^n ‚â° 1 [MOD p] := by
      have: 1 = 1^n := by simp
      nth_rw 2 [this]
      exact Nat.ModEq.pow n hh1
    nth_rw 2 [‚Üê mul_one a]
    exact Nat.ModEq.mul rfl hh2
  -- add mod, (a+b) mod p = a mod p + b mod p
  have hadd5{a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 p : ‚Ñï}:
    a1 ‚â° b1 [MOD p] ‚Üí a2 ‚â° b2 [MOD p] ‚Üí a3 ‚â° b3 [MOD p]
    ‚Üí a4 ‚â° b4 [MOD p] ‚Üí a5 ‚â° b5 [MOD p] ‚Üí
    (a1+a2+a3+a4+a5) ‚â° (b1+b2+b3+b4+b5) [MOD p] := by
    intro hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5
    apply Nat.ModEq.add ?_ hh5
    apply Nat.ModEq.add ?_ hh4
    apply Nat.ModEq.add ?_ hh3
    apply Nat.ModEq.add hh1 hh2
  -- so N mod 5 is 5+3+1+3+4 = 16
  have h2: N ‚â° 16 [MOD 5] := by
    rw [hN6]
    have h6: 6 = 5+1 := by ring
    have hh1:  5*6^5 ‚â° 5 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh2:  3*6^4 ‚â° 3 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh3:  1*6^3 ‚â° 1 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh4:  3*6^2 ‚â° 3 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh5:  4*6 ‚â° 4 [MOD 5] := by
      rw [‚Üê pow_one 6]
      rw [h6]
      apply h1
    have hh6: 16 = 5+3+1+3+4 := by ring
    rw [hh6]
    apply hadd5 hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5
  -- and N mod 7 is 17
  have h3: N ‚â° 17 [MOD 7] := by
    rw [hN8]
    have hadd6{a1 a2 a3 a4 a5 a6 b1 b2 b3 b4 b5 b6 p : ‚Ñï}:
    a1 ‚â° b1 [MOD p] ‚Üí a2 ‚â° b2 [MOD p] ‚Üí a3 ‚â° b3 [MOD p]
    ‚Üí a4 ‚â° b4 [MOD p] ‚Üí a5 ‚â° b5 [MOD p] ‚Üí a6 ‚â° b6 [MOD p] ‚Üí
    (a1+a2+a3+a4+a5+a6) ‚â° (b1+b2+b3+b4+b5+b6) [MOD p] := by
      intro hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5 hh6
      apply Nat.ModEq.add
      ¬∑ apply hadd5 hh1 hh2 hh3 hh4 hh5
      ¬∑ apply hh6
    have h8: 8 = 7+1 := by ring
    have h17: 17 = 1+2+4+1+5+4 := by ring
    rw [h8, h17]
    apply hadd6
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ apply h1
    ¬∑ rw [‚Üê pow_one (7+1)]
      apply h1
    ¬∑ rfl
  -- notice that 16 ‚â° 31 mod 5 and 17 ‚â° 31 mod 7. so N ‚â° 31 mod 35
  have h4: N ‚â° 31 [MOD 35] := by
    have hh1: N ‚â° 31 [MOD 5] := by
      apply Nat.ModEq.trans h2 rfl
    have hh2: N ‚â° 31 [MOD 7] := by
      apply Nat.ModEq.trans h3 rfl
    have hh3: 35 = 5*7 := by ring
    rw [hh3]
    have hh4: Nat.Coprime 5 7 := by norm_num
    apply (Nat.modEq_and_modEq_iff_modEq_mul hh4).mp
    exact ‚ü®hh1,hh2‚ü©
  -- notice that 31 ‚â° 66 mod 35 and 0 ‚â° 66 mod 6. so N ‚â° 66 mod 210.
  have hco: Nat.Coprime 35 6 := by norm_num
  have h5: 210 = 35 * 6 := by ring
  rw [h5]
  apply (Nat.modEq_and_modEq_iff_modEq_mul hco).mp
  constructor
  ¬∑ apply Nat.ModEq.trans h4 rfl
  ¬∑ apply Nat.ModEq.trans hm6 rfl

soln_description:
In the task, the roles of $x, y$, and $z$ are cyclically symmetric, meaning that by replacing $x$ with $y$, $y$ with $z$, and $z$ with $x$, the system of equations remains the same. Therefore, we can assume that among the three unknowns, $y$ is the (magnitude-wise) middle one, so either $x \leqq y \leqq z$ or $x \geqq y \geqq z$. The largest unknown cannot be less than 1, since the sum of the positive powers of three numbers less than 1 is less than 3. Similarly, it can be shown that the smallest unknown cannot be greater than 1. Therefore, in the two distinguishable cases, $x \leqq 1 \leqq z$, or $x \geqq 1 \geqq z$.

From the equality of the left sides of the first and second equations,

$$
y-1=\frac{1}{y}\left(\left(x^{3}-x\right)+\left(z^{2}-z^{3}\right)\right)
$$

follows, while from the first and third equations,

$$
y-1=\frac{1}{y^{2}}\left(\left(x-x^{2}\right)+\left(z^{3}-z\right)\right) .
$$

In the first case, the right side of (1) is the sum of two non-positive numbers, and the right side of (2) is the sum of two non-negative numbers; thus $y-1=0$, i.e., $y=1$. We get the same in the second case, since then the right side of (1) is non-negative, and the right side of (2) is non-positive. Substituting $y=1$ into the first two equations of the system:

$$
x+z^{3}=2=x^{3}+z^{2},
$$

thus

$$
x-x^{3}=z^{2}-z^{3}
$$

In the first case, therefore,

$$
0 \leqq x-x^{3}=z^{2}-z^{3} \leqq 0
$$

which means $x-x^{3}=z^{2}-z^{3}=0$, i.e., $x=1=z$. The only positive solution to the system of equations is therefore $x=y=z=1$.
informal_statement:
Solve the following system of equations in the set of positive numbers:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+y^{2}+z^{3}=3, \\
& y+z^{2}+x^{3}=3, \\
& z+x^{2}+y^{3}=3 .
\end{aligned}
$$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Solve the following system of equations in the set of positive numbers:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& x+y^{2}+z^{3}=3, \\
& y+z^{2}+x^{3}=3, \\
& z+x^{2}+y^{3}=3 .
\end{aligned}
$$ -/
theorem algebra_201897 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) (hz : z > 0) :
    x + y^2 + z^3 = 3 ‚àß y + z^2 + x^3 = 3 ‚àß z + x^2 + y^3 = 3 ‚Üî x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_201897 {x y z : ‚Ñù} (hx : x > 0) (hy : y > 0) (hz : z > 0) :
    x + y^2 + z^3 = 3 ‚àß y + z^2 + x^3 = 3 ‚àß z + x^2 + y^3 = 3 ‚Üî x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1 := by
  constructor
  ¬∑ -- Assume the system of equations holds, prove x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1
    rintro ‚ü®h1, h2, h3‚ü©
    have h4 : x ‚â• 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have h5 : y ‚â• 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have h6 : z ‚â• 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have h7 : x ‚â§ 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have hx1 : x = 1 := by
      nlinarith
    have h8 : y ‚â§ 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have hy1 : y = 1 := by
      nlinarith
    have h9 : z ‚â§ 1 := by
      nlinarith [sq_nonneg (x - 1), sq_nonneg (y - 1), sq_nonneg (z - 1), 
        sq_nonneg (x^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (y^2 - 1), sq_nonneg (z^2 - 1), 
          mul_pos hx hy, mul_pos hx hz, mul_pos hy hz
        ]
    have hz1 : z = 1 := by
      nlinarith
    exact ‚ü®hx1, hy1, hz1‚ü©
  ¬∑ -- Assume x = 1 ‚àß y = 1 ‚àß z = 1 prove the system.
    rintro ‚ü®rfl, rfl, rfl‚ü©
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- First equation: 1 + 1^2 + 1^3 = 3
      norm_num
    constructor
    ¬∑ -- Second equation: 1 + 1^2 + 1^3 = 3
      norm_num
    ¬∑ -- Third equation: 1 + 1^2 + 1^3 = 3
      norm_num
